tagDescription: Canada & the U.S. 197. Behring Sea - Nfld. cause of delay - Milk River - Tariff - Canada & U.S.

Canada & the U.S. 363. Memorial Service on May 20thHopes Behring Sea and Passamaquoddy will be settled before Sir W.L. leaves Ottawa. Great misfortune is International Seal Conference postponed any longer.
Canada & the U.S. 393. Enclosing papers re publication of C.O. despatches
Canada & the U.S. 424. Acquiescing in postponement of visit...Reciprocity in the Senate will have to stand over till extra session
Canada & the U.S. 310. Enclosing letter from Mr. Pope re naval vessels on Lakes
Canada & the U.S. 417. Proposed visit of Mr. Bryce to Ottawa...Does not think Reciprocity will make any political difference or weaken ties of Canada to Empire

Canada & the U.S. 324. re official despatch on Tariff...Sending memo. on German agreement...Do not think there is any danger of maximum tariff being applied to Canada. Mr. Root said publicly that it would be impossible to have a tariff war with Canada. Attitude most friendly. . .If Canada can give some concession to U.S. would give great satisfaction.

Canada & the U.S. 240. Boundaries Water Treaty. . .possession of riparian rights does not authorize disturbance of natural flow of water. Smith resolution in opinion of Bacon - & Root...superfluous - Does not affect right of Canada to take all the water needed.

Canada & the U.S. 215. Nfld's objections necessitate long discussion. . .impossible to settle before Root goes. . .If Nfld. should desire to wade arbitration what will Canada do? Fully appreciate attitude of Sir W.L. Pecuniary Claims - U.S. as anxious as Canada re Hague Tribunal Award

Canada & the U.S. 460. U.S. allege breach of faith in regard to Sir C.F.'s assurances not being carried out...Possibility or increasing the length of Notice as compromise...Encloses typewritten letter for Sir W.L.
Canada & the U.S. 427. Enclosing letter from Mr. Knox re Nashville on Great Lakes
Canada & the U.S. 187. Dept. of External Affairs only possible after General Election
Canada & the U.S. 452. Reciprocity likely to pass Senate...Seal Conference dragging owing to Japanese unreasonable demands, & lack of skill on part of U.S.
Canada & the U.S. 222. Kent's disappearance. . .Sir C. FitzPatrick to go to New York to see Kent. Mr. Crowe is summoned back to Nfld.
Canada & the U.S. 480. Uneasy at having pressed Sir W.L. & Borden Through A.F. Sladen to accept compromise as Sir C.F. denies having given any assurance to U.S.
Canada & the U.S. 340. Boundary Waters: Delay owing to form of words - Assurance of C.P.R. that arrangement is satisfactory to Canada, not yet strong enough for Parliamentary purposes -

Canada & the U.S. 228. Possibility that Boundary Waters Treaty will pass. Chief trouble is with Michigan people from Sault Ste. Marie. Though Article II is not all that Sir W.L. or we could wish...it is better than nothing - without it there could be no legal claim at all against harm done to waters crossing the boundary into other States. Inaccuracy of press reports. . .Behring Sea -

Canada & the U.S. 245. Canadian Govt. making enquiries as to amount of water Smith resolution will empower Michigan to take. Mr. Gibbons will explain informally to Canadian Club meaning of Treaty. Against publication of Mr. Bryce's Despatch & memo.
Canada & the U.S. 449. Views of H.M.G. on General Arbitration cannot be expected before 14th. . .Sealing Conference. . .Canada fair & moderate in her demands

Canada & the U.S. 259. Despatch re publishing of Treaties; advocates no change in present system of keeping Treaties secret until both sides have finally settled Treaty. Pelagic Sealing: would Canada accept share of skins as compensation? Two despatches from Washington still unanswered.

Canada & the U.S. 356. Behring Sea: Sir W.L. promises to look into matter. . .Names for submission to Mexican Govt. Sir W. Mulock, Sir Louis Jetté, Eugene La Fleur. . .latter most able. . .Sir W.L. does not feel sure that American people are as anxious as Mr. Taft for reciprocal Tariff.
Canada & the U.S. 404. Canada & Newfoundland. . .Fisheries. . .
Canada & the U.S. 416. re Trade Commissioner at Washington...Possible that an extra session will be called at Washington to put through Tariff...re appointment of Boundary Waters Commissioners

Canada & the U.S. 192. Canadian General Election. . .Bond pronounced against Confederation - Pecuniary Claims - International Waters Treaty - Behring Sea - Fisheries Arbitration. .Nfld. objects to 2 sets of questions.
Canada & the U.S. 397. Hopes to send Pelagic Sealing Despatch before long. . .
Canada & the U.S. 180. Burning of Three Rivers - International Waters - St. John's River - General election
Canada & the U.S. 334. Has communicated Mr. Fielding's view to U.S., who have decided to send Mr. Emery & Mr. Pepper to Ottawa. -
Canada & the U.S. 355. Pressing for Behring Sea settlement re Lord Kitchener's visit to U.S.

Canada & the U.S. 309. Pelagic Sealing. . .Canada to enter Conference at once. . .Presses for reply from Canadian Govt. as to Desp. Sept. 13 giving basis for agreement on Compensation. re Tariff...people of N.W.T. opposed to high tariff between Canada & U.S.

Canada & the U.S. 461. Sir W.L. protests against statement that Fitzpatrick's honour & honour of G.B. require Canada to surrender sovereign rights...Canada's agent ignored by Fitzpatrick. Nothing can be done until after elections...Cannot believe Root will wreck Treaty of Arbitration on Hague Recommendations. Canadian political situation. . .Reciprocity

Canada & the U.S. 335. Enclosing communication of U.S....The plea of preferring another meeting place to Ottawa or Washington as being less exposed to publicity does not commend itself to a Dept. which negotiates through the Press.
Canada & the U.S. 290. Behring Sea Sealing Question...U.S. not propose to suspend sealing industry altogether...offer Canada percentage of skins taken on land, or annual cost payment in lieu of same.

Canada & the U.S. 477. Americans startled by discovery of so much feeling against them in Canada...bad for settlement of outstanding questions...regrets impossibility of H.E. staying over to see the Borden team running well, & difficulty which prevents Hague Recommendations being settled before his departure.
Canada & the U.S. 315. Enclosing semi-official letter on Great Lakes question
Canada & the U.S. 301. No extra Rider asked re B.W.T. only an assurance from U.S. that storage works at St. Mary's River will be established without fail.
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 7. Garrison questionenclosing copy of letter to Balfour

Canada & the U.S. 338. Rush Bagot agreement...Asks for expression of views re Despatch sent. Thinks men with shipyards on Lakes will want to build; & prevail on President to press us to admit Roots construction of Rush Bagot, or denounce agreement - which would be a calamity: revised agreement a far smaller evil. Tariff: Concession in wood pulp best way of easing off position & letting U.S. down with enough to save their face. If they return to Washington without anything, may be tempted to defy Canada & engage in Tariff War. -
Canada & the U.S. 408. Fisheries. . .Tarriff. . .H.E.'s visit to Mr. Roosevelt & talk on Oriental question. . .
Canada & the U.S. 381. Pressing for Behring Sea settlement. . .Statement appears in B.C. paper re Canada obtaining compensation. U.S. desire to prevent disclosures as Russia & Japan may object.

Canada & the U.S. 299. Tariff: Sir W.L. thinks U.S. Treaty with Cuba as much undue discrimination as French-Canadian Treaty. If U.S. penalise Canada, she will retaliate by tax on pulp, pulp-wood etc. B.W.T. Pugsley & King going to Washington is negociate.

Canada & the U.S. 261. re conference on Waterways Treaty...Mr. Root & Mr. Gibbons agree that riparian rights on either side of river are no restriction upon diversion by the other within its own territory higher up. Treaty eminently just.

Canada & the U.S. 332. Hopes Mr. Fielding's letter of 22nd supplies necessary assistance...Iasmuch as U.S. desire is to be provided with an excuse for not inflicting maximum tariff on Canada, hopes Mr. Fielding will satisfy U.S. Rptve. that French Treaty does not involve any discrimination calling for this. Sir W.L.'s illness prevented signing of Boundary Waters Minute...H.E. keeps reminding Sir W.L. that any further delay re B.W.T. & Behring Sea - now that mind of Govt. is made up - is harmful...Position at Westminster...suggested Federation of U.K.

Canada & the U.S. 442. Great Lakes. . .U.S. have met Canadian representations very fairly. . .Morning Post publishes statement of U.S. intentions concerning Canada. . .Sir W.L. is satisfied with U.-5. answer re Great Lakes. . .
Canada & the U.S. 438. Sir W.L.'s answers to various questions put by Mr. Bryce. . .Pelagic Sealing & Great Lakes

Canada & the U.S. 468. Surprised that Fitzpatrick consider no moral obligation...re C.O. memo...Edward Grey agrees with Sir W.L. on sovereign infringement...Asks permission to send copy of H.E. letter to Geo. Young in England, so that he can talk over matter with C.O.

Canada & the U.S. 229. Chance of opposition breaking down. . .F.O. ask for publication of Treaty, before approval of Senate. Thinks such publication would be fatal to Treaty in Senate...Senate & Fisheries Treaty...Hope to get U.S. to withdraw name proposed for Hague arbitrator.
Canada & the U.S. 244. Mr. Knox does not like idea of memorandum by Mr. Bryce & Mr. Root's letter on interpretation of U.S. Govt. of amendment, being published.

Canada & the U.S. 359. B.W.T. Sir W.L. thinks any further legislation on this unnecessary until next session in order to give Canada & U.S. opportunity to consult together...Desirable that identical legislation should be passed by both countries: approach of Canadian prorogation makes it impossible to give required consideration to question.
3. AYLESWORTH AND LORD ROBSON North Atlantic Fisheries

Canada & the U.S. 339. Mr. Fielding has told N.Y. Herald man that he was completely mistaken about delay in negotiations...H.E. will ask Sir W.L. & Mr. Fielding to take an early opportunity of making a public statement in the House of C. Apart from this N.Y. Herald man has done his work well. Accused of becoming too Canadian. U.S. Commissioners demanded that advantages of Franco-Canadian Convention should be extended to U.S. but in response to enquiry whether U.S. would make concessions by which France had purchased Treaty - they refused. Canadian Govt. have resisted pressure here to prohibit export of pulp. Cannot say whether Sir W.L. would give U.S. assurance re pulp in return for free entry into U.S. of Canadian products made out of timber. Commissioners leave tomorrow...Rush Bagot: Policy of Canada to sympathise, mark time & procrastinate. Point, that in 1818 impossible to reach Lakes from sea & therefore to build on Lakes meant to maintain, good one.

Canada & the U.S. 388. re Hudson Bay Trip...Sir W.L. went off West without deciding the few & simple questions re Behring Sea. . .0ne can only suppose he wished to say at Victoria that nothing had been done.

Canada & the U.S. 466. Fitzpatrick: denies having given U.S. any assurance quâ acceptance of the recommendations. . .Suggests amendment giving 6 months notice of new regulations. Thinks a confidential memo. should be prepared
Canada & the U.S. 305. Tariff: B.W.T. - Mr. Pugsley & Mr. King to go to Washington. Behring Sea: Mr. Pope's views...Thinks these questions are on the eve of settlement
Canada & the U.S. 184. U.S. Dept. of State refrain from sending in applications for new militia training ships on Great Lakes, in consideration of feeling in Canada.
3. Subjects Duchess of Connaught Redistribution Bill Australia, proportional representation
Canada & the U.S. 307. Gridiron Club invite H.E. to Washington. B.W.T. should be no difficulty about assurance refined from U.S.

Canada & the U.S. 225. Aylesworth's presence useful - Kent behaved well. . .think Nfld. is in a more amiable frame of mind re Canada. Boundary Waters Treaty. . .exchange of notes. Bacon hopeful re Niagara Power
Canada & the U.S. 357. Mexican request. . .Behring Sea: Passamaquoddy. . .
Canada & the U.S. 241. Avoid definite & final refusal...Several expedients to be resorted to rather than lose Treaty - U.S. Govt. have behaved well.
Canada & the U.S. 195. Behring Sea. . .Nfld. - suggestion send representative meet Canada & U.S. to discuss Terms of Reference. Root leaves office March 4.
Canada & the U.S. 439. Pelagic Sealing Conference...Great Lakes...U.S. anxious to do nothing that would embarrass Canadian Ministers. Mr. Bryce's postponed visit to Ottawa
Canada & the U.S. 236. Last obstacle in way of ratification removed
Canada & the U.S. 364. re Commercial Treaty with U.S. being considered in autumn. Should be known that delay takes place by wish of the President.
Canada & the U.S. 248. Publication of memo. & Despatch would complicate matters at Washington. Reference of Treaty to Dominion Parliament a step of doubtful wisdom - raises precedent
Canada & the U.S. 242. Newfoundland. . .advisability of Union with Canada

Canada & the U.S. 378. Behring Sea. . .Mr. Templeman in Washington. satisfied with U.S. amendment regarding duration of agreement...Canada being a party to the contemplated international agreement can prevent it from running longer than she desires. Mr. Templeman explains minor objections -
Canada & the U.S. 414. Enclosing copy of a letter from Sir W.L. re Consul at Washington...Settlement of Behring Sea agreement
Canada & the U.S. 478. Enclosing copies of cables re publication in official records of Private Communications between Mr. Bryce & Sir C.F.

Canada & the U.S. 353. General satisfaction in England & Canada over Tariff question...Mr. Taft relieved...does not think of discussing reciprocity proposals till autumn. B.W.T. safe...Hope to push on Behring Sea Question.

Canada & the U.S. 476. Defeat of Sir W.L....Borden engaged forming new Cabinet...Speeches of Taft & Hill largely responsible for change of Govt..as showing independent spirit in Canada...Farewell plans
Canada & the U.S. 204. Gibbons in Ottawa - re International Waterways Treaty - Knox may be harder to deal with than Root. Root may retire about the 18th.

Canada & the U.S. 409. Agreeable impression left by Canadian Ministers in Washington. Tariff situation. . .Behring Sea Agreement. . .Fisheries. . .Oriental position & U.S. attitude. . .Germans & French uneasy over Tariff arrangements between C. & U.S.

Canada & the U.S. 295. Interview with Mr. Taft on Warships on Great Lakes - enclose memo. to Sir W.L. Mr. Taft's tone towards Canada quite friendly, but if French Treaty with Canada goes through attitude of U.S. cannot be determined.
Canada & the U.S. 407. Rush Bagot Agreement. . .new difficulties constantly arising.
Canada & the U.S. 336. U.S. Commissioners have met Sir W.L. & Mr. Fielding. Canada firm, but conciliatory
Canada & the U.S. 345. Suggests H.E. going to Washington on his way to New York. Boundary waters Treaty: Desirable that this should be accepted within next 8 days -

Canada & the U.S. 251. Mr. Gibbons at Ottawa...Conference to be held at Washington re interpretation of Smith resolution. U.S. Govt. having purchased riparian rights an assurance from Mr. Knox gives satisfactory solution. If U.S. have bought Chandler-Dunlop property with view of making new Navigation Channel at cost of $5,000,000, Canada can afford to take generous view.
Canada & the U.S. 376. Forwards semi-official letter & hopes for speedy settlement. Offers to come up to see Sir W.L. before letter goes west in July.

Canada & the U.S. 358. Tariff. . .Think majority of U.S. people in favour of reciprocal arrangements with Canada. . .Pressing for Behring Sea settlement as that Senate might accept it before it rises. . .Thinks he might see Mr. Taft & discuss reciprocity before visiting Canada in May. . .re appointment of Commissioners under B.W. Treat
Canada & the U.S. 435. re Vice Consulship for Mr. Dawson. . .Fishery Regulations. . .

Canada & the U.S. 387. Since H.E. left impossible to get anything out of Canadian Ministers. . .Habit of embodying all decisions in a Minute of Council quite unfitted for negotiations with another Power. . .Dept. of External Affairs has not accelerated matters.
Canada & the U.S.436. re Nashville on Great Lakes. . .Americans do not want to disturb existing arrangements.

Canada & the U.S. 368. re Pelagic Sealing Agreement...Indefinite cessation of sealing proposed in order to leave matter open for Conference. Simplest way to meet Canada's objection would be to insert a number of years for indefinite cessation. U.S. would agree to alteration.
Canada & the U.S. 319g. Tariff situation. . .wisdom of letting U.S. alone & not approaching them with requests for minimum tariff.

Canada & the U.S. 475. Regrets change of Govt. as making it difficult for handling questions during H.E.'s short remainder of term - with new Govt...asking for hints how best to deal with Borden & Foster & what this policy is likely to be.

Canada & the U.S. 181. Sir W.L. does not realize that U.S. Senate is master of the situation, & that neither Root nor anyone else can overcome its resistance. Root's argument ought to be met by Canada. Permanent Commission advisable. . .Three points for consideration. . .External Affairs Dept . of Canada
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 6. Garrison questionCapital case (Italian)
Canada & the U.S. 415. Uncertain of Reciprocity Agreement passing Senate...discusses probable result of the agreement if accepted...Behring Sea Treaty signed...Great Lakes
Canada & the U.S. 443 Mr. Bryce coming to Ottawa to talk with Sir W.L., Sir A. Aylesworth etc. .
Canada & the U.S. 418. U.S. attitude on Reciprocity...Champ Clark...most sensible Americans realise - that union with Canada is more unlikely now than it ever was.
Canada & the U.S. 290a. Return from West. . .American invasion. . .National Rivers & Harbours Congress
Canada & the U.S. 297. Tariff: Mr. Taft wants to avoid Tariff War, but some of his advisers want to threaten Canada with it. May be trouble between French & U.S. over Treaty.

Canada & the U.S. 238. Talk with Bacon & Root on Treaty. . .Inclined to think Canada ought to accept Treaty with Resolution. Cannot see that Canada will get any less water at the Sault than she would have done had Treaty passed in original form.
Canada & the U.S. 250. If U.S. Govt. is only interested Party in St. Mary River, should be no difficulty about obtaining satisfactory assurance from Mr. Knox re changes in American Tariff.
Canada & the U.S. 316. re N. York Herald & desire to make trouble between U.S. & Canada. . .Correspondents have bad name in Washington. Chicago Tribune better paper -

Canada & the U.S. 366. Hudson Bay impossible, as they go to S. America in August. Seal Conference greatly needed if herd is to be saved. Japanese going to attack the seals from motor boats all along the 3 mile limit. Sudden request to begin tariff negotiations has been kept secret.
Canada & the U.S. 317. U.S. State Dept. wish to propose a compromise whereby the necessity of arbitrating Passamaquoddy avoided. . .Hopes to satisfy Canada on B. Waters & Behring Sea questions soon.
Canada & the U.S. 362. re King's death...Will not visit Canada as intended.

Canada & the U.S. 205. re Canadian representative for Forestry Convention; recommends Fisher. . .Gibbons trying to push through Treaty at Ottawa. Confusion at last moment due to want of External Affairs Dept.
Canada & the U.S. 467. Reporting interview with Judge Grey & Mr. Scott...Both realize that nothing can be done until after the elections. . .
Canada & the U.S. 190. re U.S. immigration agents. . .Mackenzie King - may be selected to attend Opium Conference
Canada & the U.S. 257. Asking for answer of Canada re Behring Sea..Suggests H.E. going to Irrigation Congress at Spokane while in B.C.
Canada & the U.S. 210. Anxiously awaiting news from Washington reporting agreement between Gibbons & Pugsley - Way clear
Canada & the U.S. 413. Does not think Trade Commissioner suggestion will develop into anything serious. . .re Great Lakes: Sir W.L. has committed himself to give papers being pressed by Mr. Foster

Canada & the U.S. 450. Sir W.L. does not appear to have grasped U.S. attitude on Fisheries Award. . .U.S. led to believe (by C.J.) that Canada would accept Recommendations as part of the Award, but do not wish to drag in C.J.'s name more than necessary. U.S. fear if Canada refuses Newfoundland will also refuse. No offensive line taken by U.S.
2. Subjects International Waterways Commission
Canada & the U.S. 451. Result of Seal Conference a great triumph

Canada & the U.S. 273. Enclosing memo. on Boundary Waters Treaty...Newfoundland: Bond's paper has attacked Sir W. Macgregor. Both sides in Nfld. accuse the other of conspiring with Canada. Publication of Treaties: No use asking U.S. Govt. to give assurance re secrecy of documents; they would reply that such documents are kept secret, so far as they are concerned. It is individual members of the Senate who disclose terms.

Canada & the U.S. 361. Proposes to visit Ottawa...re Despatch on Great Lakes & shipbuilding...Taft stated in clearest terms that he did not wish to disturb existing position. Time enough to protest when we see any sign of U.S. disturbing present arrangement.
Canada & the U.S. 395. Fears Ambassador's consent was not obtained to publication of despatch. . .Presses for appointment of Commissioner under Boundary Waters Treaty

Canada & the U.S. 347. Regrets cannot visit Washington...Boundary Waters: Sir W.L. refuses to accept Treaty under present conditions. Thinks present moment inopportune as Treaty unpopular in Toronto -
Canada & the U.S. 194. U.S. Tariff Revision - J.J. Hill speaks on free trade between U.S. & Canada

Canada & the U.S. 473. On the policy of least said soonest mended...French-Canadian Nationalism a far more dangerous thing with Laurier off the chess-board...as bad as the Irish Third Party....going back to a more distracted country than we knew when we entered Parliament or even thought we should see...Root thinks Arbitration will suffer if recommendations not implemented by parties concerned...Presses for Sir W.L. acceptance of Judge Gray's suggestion of 6 months period...& urges importance of not being dragged back to the Hague again.
Canada & the U.S. 249. Meaning of Smith resolution necessary before Canada accepts. Conference between Mr. Aylesworth, Gibbons. . .Mr. Knox, Mr. Root to be arranged

Canada & the U.S. 394. Mr. Bryce hopes to be in London & asks what he can do to help on negotiations between Canada & U.S. Hague Award what he hoped for. . .Bays decision strengthens over position in more ways than one.
Canada & the U.S. 186. Congratulations Quebec. . .Gibbons sanguine of success re Boundary Waters Treaty
Canada & the U.S. 365. Sir W.L. promises to write about Behring Sea before he leaves Ottawa, but neglects to do so. Urges Mr. Bryce to accompany him to H. Bay.
Canada & the U.S. 178. General Election. . .Pecuniary Claims & Nfld. Arbitration - ought to be put through before December. re Mr. King
Canada & the U.S. 465. Enclosing letter from Sir W.L. who requires to be supplied with further evidence re Hague Recommendations.
Canada & the U.S. 377. Forwards confidential letter from Mr. Fielding
Canada & the U.S. 216. Press reports re Treaty

Canada & the U.S. 296. Pressing Sir W.L. re Behring Sea. Tariff  does not think Mr. Bryce's caveat will prevent Canada adopting French Treaty. Opening speeches at Ottawa H. of C. . .Decides not to go to Washington Congress Harbours etc.
Canada & the U.S. 202. Fisheries agreement - F.O. despatch - One chance of getting free fish for free coal is through Taft, who desires to see Tariff reduced.
Canada & the U.S. 434. Probability of General Election in Canada soon. . .Fishery Regulations...Dr. Dawson's recommendation for his son

Canada & the U.S. 237. Treaty gone through with Smith's amendment. There seems a power for the Senate to amend or vary the terms of its resolution approving of it, by passing another resolution. Bacon, Root & Knox all considered that it was safer to get Treaty through now than run risks of fresh discussion in new Senate. . .Feared that when press got hold of it difficulties would increase & Treaty might be lost. Root thinks it quite as good for Canada - & did his best to carry out what U.S. Govt. intended

Canada & the U.S. 182. Pecuniary Claims umpire & arbitrator - Mr. Roots draft provided for 3 arbitrators. Sir W.L. desires 2 Commissioners & one umpire. Canada apparently now disposed to prefer Mr. Root's first wording of draft Treaty.
Canada & the U.S. 446. Enclosing memo. on Hague Award. . .Hays Hammond brings special message from President re Dillon the Fenian whose release is wanted by U.S
Canada & the U.S. 326. State Dept. & Tariff Board clash. . .position of U.S. weak
Canada & the U.S. 419. Pecuniary Claims...Mr. Bryce's proposed visit to Canada...Attitude on British manufacturer on Taft Fielding Agreement

Canada & the U.S. 308. Mr. Pugsley goes to Washington re B.W.T. Canada prepared to go into Conference re Behring Sea; but will not agree to any proposal of suspension unless she receives adequate compensation.
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 4. Garrison question - Lake's Memo. - Fielding's visit to England etc.

Canada & the U.S. 445. Fresh Water Fisheries. . .omission of regulations said to be agreed to by Prince & Jordan. . .N. Atlantic Fisheries..Mr. Root to supply statement of facts leading to their belief that Canada would accept Recommendations as part of the Award. . .Morning Post raking trouble re Great Lakes.
Canada & the U.S. 198. Election changes in Canada - Sifton speaks in New York - re Root's suggestion of reciprocal free trade in coal...Free Trade in Canada - U.S. & U.K. would defy the world.

Canada & the U.S. 426. Mr. Bryce postpones Canadian Trip on account of Reciprocity feeling...Annexation cry foolish...nearly all sensible Americans have dropped all notion of political union...Request from U.S. to replace the Nashville on Great Lakes
2. BRYCE - LAURIER Boundary Waters North Atlantic Fisheries Boundary
Canada & the U.S. 258. re last communication on Pelagic Sealing...Sir W.L. adheres to former position re compensation to fishermen on cessation of pelagic sealing.
Canada & the U.S. 201. Draft Minute re Behring Sea - re convening of Conference. .
Canada & the U.S. 323. U.S. State Dept. publish statement that they are sending Tariff Board to Ottawa. Refuse statement that there will be no tariff war between Canada & U.S.
Canada & the U.S. 441. May 3rd for the Bryce's visit. . .Sir W.L. objects to Pecuniary Claims arrangements. . .Great Lakes. . .

Canada & the U.S. 234. Discussion re Boundary Waters Question. . .Settlement arrived at between Gibbons, Mr. Bryce, Root & Anderson  proposed amendment to resolution, giving Canada what was intended & yet avoiding what Michigan people object to.

Canada & the U.S. 369. re Commercial Treaty with U.S. in autumn...Canada desires to negotiate with other countries before dealing with U.S., but wishes delay to be undertaken by the wish of the President. Difficult to meet President's desire to open negotiations at once. Parliament prorogued & Ministers scattered. Mr. Fielding thinks delay might be to advantage of U.S. re elections in November.
Canada & the U.S. 314. Compensation to sealers. . .As no progress can be made until question of compensation settled - best to obtain this before Conference opens. . .
Canada & the U.S. 447. Fur Seal settlement...Mr. Pope's suggestions satisfactory. . .Political situation in Canada

Canada & the U.S. 294. Agrees possible embarrassment H.E. attending Congress if B.W.T. & Behring Sea remain unsettled. As Sir W.L. thought last proposal submitted re Behring Sea acceptable surprised not to have communication from Ottawa. B.W.T.: delay of nine months since Treaty went to Canada makes suggestion of changes difficult...re Tariff: Mr. Fielding's argument does not agree with indications of U.S. attitude. Anything which gives U.S. less than other countries may be considered undue discrimination.
Canada & the U.S. 437. Introducing Senator Beveridge of Indiana -
Canada & the U.S. 325. German restrictions on American cattle. U.S. had to give way. Chairman of Tariff Board not so sure of his position as he was.

Canada & the U.S. 333. State Dept. at Washington not popular...Under Secretary gives everything to the Press, who garble what he gives them. 'N.Y. Herald publish substance of Mr. Bryce's confidential letter to Mr. Knox. 'Herald' invents statement that everything passing between Ottawa & Embassy must go via the F.O. & C.O. in London, thereby causing delay of which U.S. complain. Stated that U.S. intend sending 2 Tariff Commissioners to Ottawa. Emery a good man wants to arrange things peacefully, but may be hampered by colleagues.
Canada & the U.S. 328. Every attention will be shown to Chairman of Tariff Board should he come to Canada. Canada perfectly friendly, but absolutely calm. Could stand tariff war better than U.S.

Canada & the U.S. 224. Delegates for Conservation Conference. .Fisher, Sifton & Béland. . .Mr. Aylesworth's impressions of the Embassy..suggest make statement in H. of C. re usefulness of Embassy at Washington

Canada & the U.S. 217. Nfld's representative does not have free hand. Not sanguine as to H.M. Govt. overrule Newfoundland. . .Canada is Nfld's shadow in this matter. . .Aylesworth leaves for Washington.
Canada & the U.S. 472. Enclosing copy of letter to C.O. & attached memo
Canada & the U.S. 226. Bond consults Clerk of House (U.S.) on constitutional questions. Fisheries agreement going through. Smith's opposition in Senate to Boundary Waters Treaty

Canada & the U.S. 346. Mr. Fielding to go to Albany on invitation of President. Taft seems to think Canada should be penalized by maximum. Difficulty in way of U.S. paying price satisfactory to Canada, is their inability to make any Tariff concessions without approval of Congress - Canada willing to conciliate but won't be bullied.

Canada & the U.S. 396. Recommending Mr. Hoyt who starts for Ottawa as one of the Tariff Commissioners. . .re American policy in China. . .distrust of Japanese who are supposed to be not playing the game in Manchuria. . .

Canada & the U.S. 271. Despatch on Behring Sea...Canada is gaining nothing by refusing to state what compensation she wants...the 20% of skins offered is worth having; & if there is no Conference the herd will cease.

Canada & the U.S. 318. U.S. Govt. consent to do on St. Mary's River & Milk River, what Canada desires. Passamaquoddy Bay: every possibility of U.S. accepting Canada's offer - i.e. Pope's Folly Island for whole of Disputed Fishing Ground. Behring Sea: would Canada consider $200,000 sufficient compensation? U.S. have not yet been told that Canada will enter Conference.
Canada & the U.S. 276. Sir W.L. impatient at suggestion that Smith Resolution means nothing.

Canada & the U.S. 279. Sir W.L. admits that Treaty in itself is good, but that it must be considered along with all the previous negociations that have taken place with the U.S. & past experiences make it necessary for him to guard Canada against possibility of again being jockeyed out of her rights. . .Canadian attitude on naval question

Canada & the U.S. 474. Rush Bagot Treaty & Sir W.L.'s change of view re Canadian shipbuilding yards on the Lakes...Uncertainty of Root accepting Judge Gray's suggestion re Hague Recommendation...Canadian position re Fisheries Treaty strong legally, pity to weaken it by hasty action...
Canada & the U.S. 243. re debating Waterways Treaty in Dominion Parliament. . .Chance of revision of resolution would become remote if anything said in Ottawa to offend U.S. susceptibilities.
Canada & the U.S. 392. re withholding from Council previous better to Sir R. Cartwright. . .encloses letter re Canadian dilatories which may help Mr. Bryce with U.S. executive.

Canada & the U.S. 278. Mr. Root & Attorney General both agree that Smith's object was not to affect Canada & her water rights, but only to make a good case for his Power Co. against the U.S. & any other people wanting water on the U.S. side. The Attorney General showed his opinion to Smithy who agreed with it.

Canada & the U.S. 246. Enclosing letter to Mitchell Innes...Sir W.L. realises importance of Treaty to Canada. Newfoundland: inexpediency of H.E. paying another visit to Nfld. Mr. Bryces presence there useful
Canada & the U.S. 374. Passamaquoddy Treaty signed. . .Little time left for Behring Sea settlementPresses for minor objections mentioned.
Canada & the U.S. 440. Reciprocity dragging on indefinitely...Difficulty of Mr. Bryce consulting Sir W.L. before latter leaves for England
Canada & the U.S. 466a.

Canada & the U.S. 300. Tariff: thinks Sir W.L. does not understand position. Mr. Taft most friendly, but cannot bind himself until he has gone into subject with his advisers. Afraid French Treaty may bring to other countries preferences against U.S. Presses for settlement Behring Sea
1. BRYCE - LAURIER Boundary Waters North Atlantic Fisheries Boundary
Canada & the U.S. 425. Invites Mr. Bryce to address Royal Society on 17th (April ?) Sir W.L. sails for England May 12th

Canada & the U.S. 203. Behring Sea - Mr. Bacon & Mr. Root - U.S. offers Canada percentage of skins taken on land, but declines to entertain claims for compensation by B.C. sealers, as it would lay them open to claims from Japan & Russia.
Canada & the U.S. 384. re seditious reprint appearing in B.C. of incident in Mutiny.
Canada & the U.S. 274. Ontario Govt. memorialized against Treaty in respect of Smith resolution...resolution quite inoperative against Canada.
Canada & the U.S. 265. Seizure of American poaching vessel off Vancouver. . .re Heccate Strait: what are Canadian grounds for claiming Heccate Strait as Mare Clausum?
Canada & the U.S. 382. Has seen Mr. Hoyt re Behring Sea & forwarded to Mr. Templeman statement of position.
Canada & the U.S. 212. Nfld. delay may prevent settlement of Reference to Hague, before Root retires. Pecuniary claims. . .Boundary Waters Treaty signed

Canada & the U.S. 337. Press statements re delay in negotiations owing to Embassy asking F.O. what should be done. N.Y. Herald trying to make mischief between Embassy & Canada. Thinks contradiction should be made; no truth in statement that Embassy misled Canada into thinking U.S. would grant minimum.

Canada & the U.S. 206. Behring Sea - Sir W.L. refuses suggestion of percentage on skins. Miss Cadenhead - similar parallel in Chinese riots at Vancouver - compensation paid. . .International Waters re insertion of Chicago clause - Sir W.L. reluctantly defers his judgment to Gibbons. . .Milk River

Canada & the U.S. 263. re German desire to become friendly with Canada. F.O. does not think Washington should be centre of such negotiations. Champlain Tercentenary...Invitation to H.E. to go. Who is to represent Canada at Alaska Yukon Exposition?
Canada & the U.S. 457a. U.S. press for all Hague recommendations to be accepted. Mr. Bryce temporizes
Canada & the U.S. 262. Mr. Aylesworth pleased with his Washington visit...Canada could not be in worse position at the Sault, & may be in a better one by accepting Treaty with Senate resolution.
Canada & the U.S. 354. Behring Sea:...Tariff. . .nothing could have been better than Canada's management of the affair.
Canada & the U.S. 280. Forwarded memo. to Sir W.L....External Affairs Dept. created...Passamaquoddy: Mr. King at Washington with authority to act.
Canada & the U.S. 371. Sir W.L. in Quebec...Mr. Fielding regrets impossibility of entering into Tariff negociations with U.S. until after he has dealt with Belgium & Italy, who have both strong case.
Canada & the U.S. 286. Return of H.E. to Ottawa. . .Hitch in Boundary Waters Treaty
Canada & the U.S. 405. Conference on Fishery Regulation...Canada & Newfoundland prepared to notify minor objections but stand firm on important ones. . .Tariff. . .Newfoundland & U.S. . .
Canada & the U.S. 351. Tariff business satisfactorily settled; both sides pleased. . .Fielding managed extremely well & impressed Taft favourably.

Canada & the U.S. 270. Thinks the Council, as a whole, are favourable to Treaty, but that Sir W.L. is marking time. Aylesworth thinks Canada is stronger with the Treaty than without it. Publishing of Treaties: Sir W.L. agrees that it is most undesirable to publish Treaties after signature & before ratification, but U.S. must give assurance that Treaties under discussion by Senate shall not be divulged, until ratified...Mr. Lemieux to represent England & Canada at Champlain Celebration

Canada & the U.S. 469. American view is that compromise intended to cover not only existing but future regulations..& that both parties impliedly bound themselves to accept recommendations in entirety...To meet Canadian objection six months notice of new regulations suggested...
Canada & the U.S. 373. Sir W.L. in Quebec. . .H.E. has written to him fully on Behring Sea Question.
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 10. Re suggested message of condolence to Charter Co. - death of Jones
Canada & the U.S. 207. Amendments to Boundary Waters Treaty from F.O. - no possible objection - more or less formal amendments - time precious - misfortune to lose the Treaty

Canada & the U.S. 289. Enclosing letter from Secretary of State inviting H.E. to Conference National Rivers & Harbours Dec. 8-10. Uneasy over number of U.S. war ships on Great Lakes...Pribyloff Islands: Sir W.L. thinks U.S. should give Canada sum of money down, from which, they can pay sealers compensation. Passamaquoddy Bay - Personal visit by Mr. Bryce who made inspection & wrote Despatch. Matter will have to go to arbitration as U.S. won't agree to proposal of Canada submitted by King.

Canada & the U.S. 481. Sir C.F. gave the impression or considering himself bound in honour &. regarded the matter as most serious...Borden cannot be expected to do anything that would expose him to Sir W.L.'s criticism...Thinks Canada & Newfoundland could be dealt with separately.

Canada & the U.S. 283. Little hope of outstanding questions being settled at early date. Sir W.L. confused Heccate & Gehring Sea Questions, & referred to new External Affairs Dept. Sir W.L. still hesitating over Waterways Treaty...Future correspondence to go through Governor General, not withstanding new External Affairs Dept....Strongly advise Mr. B. going to Nfld...Canadian navy questions
Canada & the U.S. 430. The opposition attitude on Reciprocity. . .

Canada & the U.S. 227. Delegates to Conservation Conference - Boundary Waters Treaty - Opposition to Treaty in Senate would cause Canadian people to regard it more favourably. Behring Sea: Sir W.L. thinks U.S. only people who would benefit by cessation of Pelagic Sealing - consequently should compensate people who give up right of sealing in open sea. . .Nfld. - visit from Mr. Bryce most useful
Canada & the U.S. 319. Forwarding Desp. re U.S. agreement Boundary Waters Treaty; could not make an international agreement more binding...Work begun: probably finished in 3 years.
6. Subjects Century of Peace Marconi scandal Hon. Lloyd George
Canada & the U.S. 401. Mexican Boundary Arbitration question. . .Mr. Lafleur suggested as Canadian nominee.
Canada & the U.S. 211. Memo. from Washington. . .Pinchot to represent United States at Conference. Canadian representative not chosen yet. .Boundary Waters Treaty. . .Loss of Treaty and be calamity

Canada & the U.S. 341. Enclosing copy of a secret Despatch to Crewe. Tariff: Americans return to U.S. Sir W.L. thinks they have no case...cannot prove any discrimination against them. Rush Bagot: Sir W.L. thinks H.E. went too far in letter of 10th & asks him to banish from mind of Embassy any suggestion that Lake Shipyards might be permitted, in accordance with Roots contention, to build ships for ocean purposes, without a violation of the spirit of the R.B. Convention.
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 3. Garrison questionLake invaluable & sh. remain hereInternational Waterways Commission
5. Subjects Century of Peace celebration
Canada & the U.S. 470. President Taft asks for Sir W.L. advice as to his speech on Reciprocity & annexation
Canada & the U.S. 340a. Return of U.S. Commissioners

Canada & the U.S. 386. Sir W.L. says Behring Sea Minute passed. . .Hopes Pecuniary Claims also on fair way to settlement. Tariff: Sir W.L. advises no move. . .Thinks Free Trade between U.S. & Canada in natural products, advantageous to Canada.
Canada & the U.S. 412. Canada's attitude on Taft-Fielding agreement. . .strong feeling against it in important quarters. . .re Duke of Connaught's appointment
Canada & the U.S. 410. Announcing Sir W.L.'s proposal to have a Trade Commissioner at Washington...& enquiring at to his particular duties & status

Canada & the U.S. 269. Sir W.L. returns to old objections re Boundary Waters Treaty. . .quite misconceives effect of Smith Resolution. Enclose copy of letter to Sir W.L...grave misfortune if Canada rejects Treaty. re Newfoundland
Canada & the U.S. 360. Pressing for decision Behring Sea...Japanese sealers going to lie in wait & capture seals off Pribyloff where Canadians can't go.

Canada & the U.S. 319b. B.W. Treaty. . .Canada's delay is stopping Irrigation Works to be constructed. . .More than a year since Treaty was signed...Pelagic Sealing. . .U.S. complain of being unable for 3 years to obtain reply to Mr. Root's proposal of 1906.
Canada & the U.S. 350. B.W. Treaty. . .no greater misfortune could happen than its loss. Root uneasy lest some proposals should come up to complicate situation.

Canada & the U.S. 284. Boundaries W. Treaty...Folly to reject Treaty...Agrees that External Affairs Dept. should make no difference to correspondence between Embassy & Governor General re Nfld. Hope Canada will not reject Waterways Treaty without giving Embassy a chance of explaining any difficulty.
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 9. Sending Debate on AddressCanada & the Empire & Govt. policy generally - Retention of Lake
Canada & the U.S. 459. Hague RecommendationsSir C.F. not an agent therefore cannot bind Canada by assurances. . .
Canada & the U.S. 420. re proposed visit
Canada & the U.S. 268. Aylesworth thinks Waterways Treaty may not be accepted, as some of his colleagues object to Smith resolution. Can anything be done to help?

Canada & the U.S. 391. Behring Sea: Went as far as he could without appearing to hustle Sir W.L. Invitations for proposed Conference should be sent out now. . .so that it should meet before end of year. Thinks W. Indies trip in Canadian Battleship splendid idea. . .Federal question. . .Thinks sphere of imperial legislature would be small & that it would lose by absence of Scotch & Welsh members. . . (Interesting letter only Federal question)

Canada & the U.S. 230. U.S. interpretation of Boundary Waters Treaty. . .Sault Ste. Mary. . .Bacon has done his best for the Treaty - trust this resolution will cause no hitch - does not materially affect Canada
Canada & the U.S. 453. Almost certain that Reciprocity will be passed soon. Mr. Pope at Washington
Canada & the U.S. 267. Questions of Heccate St. & Passamaquoddy Bay referred to different Depts. Sir W.L. regrets delays consequent on lack of External Affairs Dept.
Canada & the U.S. 380. Tariff negociations. . .U.S. surprised at general impression that she could not take up Tariff question till autumn. Enclosing copy of a letter to Sir W.L. re Pecuniary Claims.
Canada & the U.S. 312. re N. York Herald reports, on Consuls & Canadians abroad
Canada & the U.S. 287. re lack of reliable British news in American papers
Canada & the U.S. 219. Treaty goes through. re Confederation for Nfld. - Mr. Crowe. . .Bond's position. .
Canada & the U.S. 260. Sir W.L. writes that ten U.S. war vessels are to take part in demonstration at Toledo, & that protest should be made.
Canada & the U.S. 379. Proposal about cessation harmless because whole thing depends on arrangement being made at Conference. If ten years suspension preferred, quite sure U.S. will agree.
Canada & the U.S. 329. Enclosing letter from Mr. Fielding...Canada has friendliest feelings towards U.S. but will not be bullied..
Canada & the U.S. 432. Fisheries Regulation Question. . .Trouble arises from different interpretation put upon memorandum by Aylesworth & the U.S. Executive.

Canada & the U.S. 448. Pressing for settlement of Arbitration Treaty. . .Seal Conference...Mr. Bryce supported Mr. Pope in everything even untenable contentions. . .sudden change of front...Canada willing to take what the agreement gave her. . .Not for H.M.G. to suggest any course. . .Reciprocity. . .opinion fluctuating. . .Fisheries Award. . .complications difference between Fitzpatrick & Aylesworth. . .Monroe Doctrine: most we can aim at a sort of 'entente of reciprocal consultation.
Canada & the U.S. 282. Desires answer re Behring Sea & advisability of visiting Newfoundland In July or August.
Canada & the U.S. 402. Informing him that Messrs. Fielding, Paterson, Brodeur & Sir A. Aylesworth are going to Washington for Tariff & Fisheries negotiations. .
Canada & the U.S. 456. Reciprocity cannot pass in Canadian Parlt. soon...Sir W.L. still thinks Canada in no way committed by Sir C.F.
Canada & the U.S. 469a.

Canada & the U.S. 255. Real tariff struggle will come later. Will Canada send anyone to California to look after progress of Tariff Bill? Protectionist interest against free timber & free fish very strong...If what Root, Bacon & Anderson told me was correct, I cannot imagine how the Smith resolution could give the Yankees 7/8 of water. Trouble due to the apparently accidental line of international boundary in the river, but deeper channel is on Canadian side, so natural flow gives her 2/5, & Smith resolution cannot be held to give more than natural unimpeded flow.
Canada & the U.S. 189. re complaint against U.S. immigration agents on frontier

Canada & the U.S. 233. Boundary Waters Treaty. . .Difference of opinion as to meaning & effect of U.S. proposal. . .Suggests conference with Gibbons at Washington. . .Importance of Treaty necessitates all efforts being made to arrive at settlement. Trouble in Senate arises from fact that State rights of Michigan held to be involved.

Canada & the U.S. 223. re Canadian Delegates to Conference for Conservation of Resources....Invitation from Embassy to meet Pinchot & others. Mr. Fisher to stay at Embassy. Still awaiting Bonds answer to arbitration Agreement. . .Boundary Waters Treaty thought to be safe
Canada & the U.S. 313. Sir W.L.'s statement in H. of C. of appreciation of Mr. Bryce's services. . .re Canadian attaché at Washington . . .American newspaper agencies established in Ottawa.

Canada & the U.S. 399. re sensitiveness of Canadian Govt. in their relations with F.O. good suggestion to have member of Embassy visit Ottawa from time to time. . .but if Sir Edward Grey could visit Canada it would do good.
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 1. General sketch of affairs - Booth Tucker's project - Canada & the U.S. - Halifax & Esquimalt. - R.M.C. Kingston -
Canada & the U.S. 428. Puzzled at Canadian opposition to Reciprocity...Thinks it is a mere political trick. . .

Canada & the U.S. 306. Warships on Great Lakes...As U.S. authorities seem to understand Canadian point of view formal Despatch unnecessary. May suggest revision of Rush Bagot Treaty. Attitude of U.S. administration seems altogether friendly.

Canada & the U.S. 208. Behring Sea: Root suggested giving Canada share of skins on land out of proceeds of W.L.: sealers might get compensation - re Conference - Sealing ceased to be profitable in U.S. Miss Cadenhead - F.O. suggest U.S. prosecuting soldier - Pecuniary claims. . .Nfld. arbitration - Presses for drafts on above
4. Subjects Reciprocity Borden cabinet
Canada & the U.S. 319c. Sir W.L. decides not to send Mr. Pugsley to Washington. . .but is forwarding a statement prepared by Mr. Pugsley for the information of U.S.

Canada & the U.S. 293. Mr. Fielding's view of French Treaty & U.S. Canada's action shows no discrimination against U.S. Boundary Waters Treaty shelved because of interpretation of clause 6; awaits return of Mr. Oliver to Ottawa...re Rivers & Harbours Congress - H.E. does not wish to go so long as B.W.T. questions remain unsettled.
Canada & the U.S. 179. Waterways - No move is to be expected from U.S. in way of concessions. Impossible to get Senate agree to Clinton Gibbons Treaty.
Canada & the U.S. 342. Enclosing copy of Secret Desp. Giving statement of U.S. Commissioners visit.

Canada & the U.S. 411. U.S. drop request re Torpedo Boat going through Lakes...Request from Canadian Govt. for publication of Correspondence re Great Lakes etc. Mr. Bryce deprecates such action...as stirring up American & Canadian press. Encloses letter to Mr. Fielding on Tariff situation...
Canada & the U.S. 455. Pelagic Sealing Conference...Mr. Pope's work appreciated...good Treaty for Canada...Hague Recommendations...Appointment of Boundary Waters Commissioners. . .
Canada & the U.S. 232. Enclosing letter of same date. . .Burton of Ohio hopes to pass Rivers & Harbours Bill under which the Michigan people who raised opposition to Treaty, would be bought out.
2. AYLESWORTH AND LORD ROBSON North Atlantic Fisheries
Canada & the U.S. 199. Mr. Scott's memo. on Cadenhead case
Canada & the U.S. 183. re interview with Sir W.L. - Sir W.L. firmly decided on having fixed principles for Boundary Waters Treaty. . .Otherwise leave matters in statu quo' Behring Sea. Ewarts book
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 11. General - Garrison question - Lake Fielding - Rider Haggard - incarnation of A. Hamilton
1. Subjects Pecuniary Claims
Canada & the U.S. 319a. Delay in coming to decision re B.W. Treaty..Mr. Pugsley to go to Washington. . .

Canada & the U.S. 302. Tariff: Mr. Taft has expressed no desire to penalise Canada, but does not wish to be pressed for final opinion yet. Cuba argument does not apply. Most favoured nation clause affects position. U.S. more to lose than gain by Tariff War.
Canada & the U.S. 421. Position of Britain under most favoured nation clause. . .would give satisfaction in England if Preference were raised by Canada...Annexation talk silly

Canada & the U.S. 214. Mr. Young goes to Ottawa to see Aylesworth & Sir W.L. Should H.M.G. seeing that Nfld. remains silent. Go on & sign agreement - Pecuniary claims - U.S. have made concessions. . .does Canada approve?

Canada & the U.S. 400. Mr. Young's visit to Ottawa most useful...Pelagic Sealing question practically settled. . .Discusses tariff situation. . .Atlantic Fisheries award. . .proposed new site for British Embassy.
Canada & the U.S. 319d. Pelagic Sealing. . .most anxious to know if $200,000 compensation will satisfy Canada. . .Great Lakes
Canada & the U.S. 220. Arbitration Treaty provisionally signed - Mr. Root resigned office. Kent going to Ottawa - doing his best to make Bond waive some futile objections..
Canada & the U.S. 422. Fisheries agreement...Pecuniary Claims...Pelagic Sealing Conference can be convoked at once...also members of the Boundaries Water Commission appointed
1. AYLESWORTH AND LORD ROBSON North Atlantic Fisheries
Canada & the U.S. 303. Mr. Pope's views on Behring Sea...Does not think conference necessary. What amount of compensation would U.S. give?

Canada & the U.S. 463. In reply to Sir W.L.'s resolve to disavow Fitzpatrick, Mr. Bryce would say that F. is a Canadian & taken by the U.S. to represent Canada at they would consider themselves unfairly dealt with...Trying to get a more explicit statement on paper of U.S. contention...

Canada & the U.S. 343. Tariff: Sir W.L. seems to have played game well. Emery not to blame...He wanted to go to Ottawa quietly to see how the land lay. Public mission has made it more difficult for U.S. to recede; but political position makes it probable that they will recoil from a Tariff War. J. Macdonald of 'Toronto Globe' has been seeing politicians & talks of suggesting to Sir W.L. a quid pro quo' - i.e. reduction of duties on articles with little competition -
Canada & the U.S. 193. Fisheries Arbitrator. . .Bond will not touch question until after elections.
Canada & the U.S. 429. President Taft is sure of carrying agreement through both Houses. . .
Canada & the U.S. 256. German Ambassador accepts invitation to Govt. House Ottawa re commercial relations - Germany prepared to give Canada most favoured nation treatment, if Canada remove surtax.

Canada & the U.S. 304. Pelagic Sealing: Time of suspension not settled...Russia & Japan pressing for - Conference - Conference necessary to discuss term of suspension: & to make authoritative regulations - Refers to - Despatch of Sept. 13 as embodying views.
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 2. Garrison question - Precedence - Mixed marriages
Canada & the U.S. 403. Giving a full account of the Tariff situation between U.S. & Canada. .
Canada & the U.S. 390. Proposed trip to W. Indies in Winter. .Position in England. . .Irish & Federalism.
Canada & the U.S. 348. B.W. Treaty. . .Pressing for speedy acceptance of Treaty...re Tariff War...Mr. Taft & State Dept. construe tariff law differently to Sir W.L.
Canada & the U.S. 231. Gibbons maintains that Rider will prevent commission giving Canada the half of the surplus waters to which she is entitled under Treaty. Sir W.L. not quite convinced of this.
Canada & the U.S. 433. Opening of Fur Seals Conference on May 18
Canada & the U.S. 275. Memorandum by Mr. Bryce. . .List of Despatches & Letters on Smith resolution
Canada & the U.S. 383. Sir W.L. adamant in being too preoccupied to consider Behring Sea Questions.
Canada & the U.S. 455. Pelagic Sealing Conference...Mr. Pope's work appreciated...good Treaty for Canada...Hague Recommendations...Appointment of Boundary Waters Commissioners. . .

Canada & the U.S. 252. New Tariff...highly protective. . .minimum will apply to Britain & her possessions, so long as preference is purely ImperialIf preference given to foreign countries, maximum will apply. Would Canada meet Germany's overtures in friendly spirit?

Canada & the U.S. 191. Fisheries Arbitration. . .Canada waiting for Nfld. to convey terms. Two sets of questions will not damage Canadian case. Chamberlain Bayard Treaty - Few signs in U.S. of a disposition towards Free Trade - Pecuniary Claims - International Waters Treaty - Behring Sea - General position of politics in U.S. - Root desires to clean the slate as much as possible before he resigns office.

Canada & the U.S. 331. Tariff: asks for some official statement re tariff...Embassy so far has no committed Canada in any way. Position complicated by the jealousy & disjunction of State Dept. & Tariff Board...Protectionists press for maximum scale...Paper-making interest fears suffer from Quebec pulp law. Amour propre' of State Dept. involved. Canada will lose nothing by allowing them to show their land.

Canada & the U.S. 221. Position of Nfld. Kent left New York. . .Senate discussing Boundary Waters Treaty. No perfect copies of Treaty available except through U.S. Govt. . .Canadian feeling re lack of knowledge in H. of C. on Treaty, & non-possession of copy
Canada & the U.S. 311. re question of Canadian attaché to Embassy. . .H.M.G. does not pay attachés - Suggests Rhodes scholar for position.
Canada & the U.S. 398. Mr. Knox's friendly feeling towards Great Britain sincere & deep; most anxious to co-operate with Canada. Asks reason for delay
Canada & the U.S. 319e. St. Mary & Milk River. . .U.S. will give assurance Canada desires.
Canada & the U.S. 406. Fishery Regulations. . .negotiations going smoothly...Much more difficulty over Tariff negotiations.
Canada & the U.S. 238a. Different interpretation of Smith amendment by Sir W.L. & Aylesworth - nothing settled. . .Aylesworth very useful
Canada & the U.S. 454. Reciprocity...Hague Recommendations...U.S. believe assurance was given to them & felt hurt at Canada's Treatment. Mr. Bryce thinks Canada is bound by Sir C.F. private promise
Canada & the U.S. 188. Canada represented at Opium Conference - Bacon suggests Mackenzie King.

Canada & the U.S. 264. Attorney General's opinion on Smith Resolution not yet considered by Sir W.L. Better prospect of friendly relations between U.S. & Canada. Mr. Root & Mr. Bryce to be congratulated on bringing this about.

Canada & the U.S. 320. Mr. Bryce leaves for Florida...Talk with Newell has cleared up Milk & St. Mary River questions. Despatch will reach Ottawa soon. Too good a bargain to lose. Present State Dept. most ill organized & unsatisfactory. If U.S. explanations still unsatisfactory suggests Mr. Pugsley should visit Washington. Passamaquoddy now agreed upon.

Canada & the U.S. 367. Despatch re Pecuniary Claims Convention...Agreement practically in its original form...George Young has taken a copy to show to Mr. Aylesworth, & if the latter is satisfied, hope H.M.C. Govt. will express concurrence & get the agreement through as soon as possible.

Canada & the U.S. 321. Despatch re St. Mary River...Talks with Newell & Chandler Anderson confirm belief that statements made about dam well founded...If Alberta people not satisfied must remember they would be much worse off without Treaty, as U.S. could then divert more than their half of river.

Canada & the U.S. 288. Injurious effects of Boundary Waters Treaty...according to American who interviewed Sir W.L. Position in England...Press Conference, & education of radical overseas press men...Defence Conference...Attitude of Colonies on Naval Defence...Botha great success in S.A.
Canada & the U.S. 218. Request that Canada should join in Conference re Sealing. Non-appearance of Kent, everybody waiting at Washington. re Delegates for Conference Natural resources
Canada & the U.S. 457. Hague TribunalSir W.L.'s views

Canada & the U.S. 385. Still anxious to come to Ottawa specially to see Sir W.L. on Behring Sea & Pecuniary Claims. Tariff: State Dept. have not indicated regret at postponement of negociations. Why not offer India to Roosevelt if he would become a British subject?! Probable that B.C. statement re Seal compensation originated in Washington, as State Dept. disorganized & careless.

Canada & the U.S. 298. Tariff: Canada right in her attitude of dignified silence & detachment...U.S. now realise that Canada doesnt need any favours from them. Will not mention subject to U.S. unless Canada desires.
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 5. Garrison questionSir C. Parson's views etc.
Canada & the U.S. 431. re closure & opposition obstruction. . .Sifton able but has no faith in moral forces.
Canada & the U.S. 254. re Conference at Washington...Time in California very profitable...Learnt great deal about Japanese position

Canada & the U.S. 213. Nfld. delay re Reference to Hague. . .Sir W.L. makes it easy for Nfld. to come into the Dominion. Thinks Bond has not recovered from disappointment that Sir W.L. decided against him re O. in C. Since then Nfld. has not shown eagerness to consider suggestions from Ottawa. Miss Cadenhead. .
Canada & the U.S. 277. Enclosing memo. on Treaty...Attorney General's opinion covers everything...Smiths object was to increase value of Power Co.'s rights against U.S., not against Canada.
Canada & the U.S. 389. Sir W.L. writes that the only reason Behring Sea question not disposed of was dispension of Council & that U.S. cannot feel slighted. .

Canada & the U.S. 349. B.W. Treaty. . .Thought Tariff tension was all the more reason why B.W. Treaty should be accepted now. Mark of good feeling to accept it irrespective of other feelings. . .Sir W.L. quite mistaken in thinking present acceptance would be regarded as weakness by U.S. What does local opposition from Toronto signify compared to enormous value of taking these water questions out of sphere of controversy & probable strife?
Canada & the U.S. 465a.
Canada & the U.S. 327. Has shown confidential communications to Laurier & Fielding. . .View in Canada is that Franco-Canadian Convention does not involve any undue discrimination against U.S.
Canada & the U.S. 464. Hague Recommendations. . .Elections. . .Judge Gray going to Montreal to talk over matters with Fitzpatrick.

Canada & the U.S. 330. Though Canada will lose less than U.S. by a Tariff War it is better to avoid one. Pressing for decision re Boundary Waters Treaty; main thing is that both countries will have an equal share of water. Mr. Newell says U.S. could not store any further for St. Mary's River, owing to nature of ground. He declares it far easier & safer to store that water inside the Canadian border.

Canada & the U.S. 423. Strong feeling in Montreal & Toronto against Reciprocity...Speech by Mr. Sifton in the H. of C. made great impression...under the circumstances thinks it inopportune for Mr. Bryce to visit Canada
Canada & the U.S. 375. Sir W.L. slow to move re Behring Sea. . .Says he is not satisfied with U.S. attitude.
Canada & the U.S. 372. re Summer plans - desires to see H.E. before his return to England.
Correspondence with Mr. Lyttelton 8. Montreal visit'fusion of races'
Canada & the U.S. 458. Hague RecommendationsProrogation of Canadian Parlt.
Canada & the U.S. 272. Sir W.L. troubled over Pugsley incident.

Canada & the U.S. 344. Consternation at idea of Tariff War. . .Canada would do well to express willingness to negotiate further - & to make it easier for the U.S. to climb down. Boundary Waters Treaty: Thinks it would have good effect to sign this Treaty now. Great Lakes: Agrees with Sir W.L.'s view

Canada & the U.S. 200. H.E. returns from Montreal. Behring Sea - Canada agrees to ten years preservation, with compensation to sealers for fishing destroyed. . .Sir W.L. opposes reciprocity in coal, unless free fish, etc. given in return. Roosevelt's success. . .International Waters
Canada & the U.S. 209. Continued absence of Department for External Affairs. . .Causes difficulties & delays, loss of favourable moments etc.

Canada & the U.S. 291. Rush Bagot Treaty...Sir W.L. view re a formal Treaty in place of above...Boundary Waters Treaty still unsettled - Madness to lose what gives Canada so much. Sir W.L. approves Conference re Seal Question - Need for Conference urgent. U.S. Tariff difficulties in connection with France & Canada

Canada & the U.S. 370. U.S. ought to have spoken re tariff negotiations before Canadians Parliament prorogued. Though Mr. Fielding's absence in England a good excuse it might be considered wise to let U.S. begin in August if they want to. Little progress could be made, but it would look better. Behring Sea: U.S. have acceded to Canadian alteration re cessation to suspension.
ALERT CASE North Atlantic Fisheries Case of U.S. vessel Alert, Magdalen Islands
Canada & the U.S. 185. Congratulations on Quebec. . .F.O. & C.O. approve having two sets of questions; but fear Nfld. may object. External Affairs Dept.
Canada & the U.S. 253. German Ambassador re Canada & Germany - would like to improve situation, but 'amour propre' stood in the way.
Canada & the U.S. 471. Has sent information to Young so that he can see F.O. & C.O....Fitzpatrick writes that Gray recommends U.S. acceptance of 6 months notice amendment
Canada & the U.S. 463.a Sir C.F. is to meet Judge Gray.
Canada & the U.S. 281. re Naval score...created bad impression in U.S....old British qualities questioned...Nothing more to be said on Waterways Treaty.

Canada & the U.S. 479. Regretting inability to stay & see the new Cabinet established...Hopes to persuade C.O. on return to London to bring pressure on Borden so that he may accept recommendations made by Mr. Bryce...Thinks Sir W.L. will refrain from harassing Mr. Borden on Fisheries question.

Canada & the U.S. 322. Sir W.L. desires to make good his statement that U.S. would build storage works from which both countries would benefit. . .Dennis C.P.R. Irrigation officer sent for to give advice re possibility of Alberta storing water...Royal Society meeting at Ottawa, May l7th.

Canada & the U.S. 266. Passamaquoddy Bay...Mr. Aylesworth suggested sending Canadian representative to Washington to discuss matter with Mr. Chandler Anderson. Interests at issue insignificant & state Dept. well disposed.

Canada & the U.S. 239. re sending Chandler Anderson to Canada to discuss Smith resolution...Even if Canada cannot accept Treaty, should not make any precipitate rejection. There are means by which Canada can be safe for 4 years & by that time a new Treaty will be in course of negotiation. Publication of Treaty...Trouble arose from comments in Canadian Press & London Times...Canadian cables...Taft & Knox helped Bacon to overcome Smith resolution. . .re Fisheries Arbitration & appointment of Drago
Canada & the U.S. 292. Pressing for decision re Boundary Waters Treaty. . .French Treaty - & U.S. objections. . .Pressing for settlement Behring Sea Seal Question

Canada & the U.S. 319f. Sir W.L. will send Mr. Pugsley to Washington if necessary, to explain reasons urged in his statement by suggestion of Canada should be accepted by U.S....Pelagic Sealing offer to be considered by Council..Great Lakes...Sir W.L. does not wish to make any move in this matter...

Canada & the U.S. 247. Sir W.L. says that if Mr. Aylesworth agrees with M. Gibbons that Smith resolution does not give U.S. as much water as he (Smith) thinks it does, we can arrange to exchange notes. Nothing done re explanation of Treaty. . .Sir W.L. says 5/8 of surplus water might be given: Smith wants 7/8. -
Canada & the U.S. 235. Memo. by H.E....Interview with Sir W.L., Mr. Gibbons & Mr. Aylesworth re Smith amendment to Treaty. . .Sir W.L. objected to accepting the resolution
Canada & the U.S. 352. Enclosing letter from Mexican. . .Ambassador re Canadian arbitrator in dispute between U.S. & Mexico. . .Ask for submission of 3 names.
Canada & the U.S. 196. re Cadenhead claim for compensation
Canada & the U.S. 444. Fishery Regulations. . .Thinks Sir W.L. is under a misapprehensionundesirable to spoil arbitration for trifling difference. .
Canada & the U.S. 285. Sir E. Morris staying with Mr. Bryce...seems to wish to do right...public opinion not ripe for Confederation
